journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Effects of the transition rate uncertainty on the steady state probabilities of Markov models using interval arithmetic

contrib-group.aff: Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad, Central de Venezuela, Apartado Postal 47937, Los Chaguaramos, Caracas 1041A, Venezuela. email: crocco@reacciun.ve; croccoucv@gmail.com

abstract.p: Markov models are often used to assess the reliability or availability of a system. Such assessment generally involves calculations of the steady state probability for each possible state in the system by solving a linear system of simultaneous equations based on the transition rates between states or using ad hoc algorithms such as the state reduction algorithm. Transition rates are usually subject to uncertainty. This paper proposes the use of interval arithmetic as an alternative approach for dealing with uncertainties in the transition rates that are modelled through lower and upper bounds. Interval arithmetic takes into account the uncertainty of all the parameters and is able to provide strict bounds with only one evaluation. The interval version of the state reduction algorithm, with additional procedures to enhance its precision, is proposed as an alternative method to evaluate uncertainty propagation. Several examples illustrate the proposed approach. Results are compared with other classical approaches, such as Monte Carlo simulation or solving a linear system of simultaneous equations.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Markov chains have been used to compute measures such as reliability and availability in a system [1–4]. The assessment of such performance functions is based on building the transition rate (TR) matrix, representing the possible transition between states, and solving a set of simultaneous equations to quantify the probability of each state πi. In general, these probabilities are evaluated for steady state conditions, solving a linear system (LS) of equations using classical methods from numerical analysis, such as classical decomposition methods or the Gauss–Seidel iterative method [5].

It must be noted that TRs are, in general, estimated from measurements, and hence they are subject to uncertainty. A decision maker could be interested in knowing how uncertainty in the TRs (e.g. failure or repair rate uncertainties) affects steady state probabilities the most. This analysis is termed uncertainty propagation; they are methods for calculating the uncertainty in the model outputs induced by the uncertainties in its inputs [6].

Several approaches based on different techniques have been considered to assess the effects of uncertainties in Markov models. Hartfiel [7] used the theory of Markov set chains; Kozine and Utkin [8] presented an approach based on linear programming; De Cooman et al. [9] considered imprecise theory and proposed several linear programming models; Škulj [10] and Crossman and Škulj [11] applied ‘general imprecise probabilistic models, known under the name interval probabilities’.

There are other approaches [12, 13], such as numerical possibility theory, evidence theory, belief function, and fuzzy random variables, that could be used in a situation of limited knowledge. However, to the present author’s best knowledge, such approaches have not been applied to analyse the effects of uncertainties in Markov models.

Recently, for assessing the importance of TRs in dynamic systems ‘including inter-components and functional dependencies’, Do Van et al. [14, 15] have proposed the use of sensitivity measures based on partial derivatives and represented as Markov models. Even if these measures tends to be computationally efficient [14, 16, 17], they correctly describe only the local behaviour of the model. The effects of uncertainties could be evaluated using Taylor-series expansion [18] but such procedures are ‘difficult or very costly to obtain’ [2].

Modelling TR uncertainties in Markov models could also be analysed on the basis of two general approaches. The first is a probabilistic approach where the probability density functions (PDFs) for some or all uncertainties are assumed and their effects are propagated under a Monte Carlo (MC) simulation.

The second approach to modelling TR uncertainties in Markov models is referred to as ‘unknown but bounded’ where the upper and lower limits on the uncertainties are assumed without a probability or possibility structure [19, 20]. Characterizing the uncertainty in parameter values with intervals is referred to as ‘incertitude’ and is used in the absence of evidence about the likelihoods of unknown quantities [21]. This approach is based on interval arithmetic (IA), a technique that takes into consideration the uncertainty of all the parameters, treating them as ‘interval numbers’ whose ranges contain the uncertainties in those parameters.

Clearly the use of interval values produces less information than the results of a complete MC method when distributions are known. MC uncertainty analysis provides a global view as it considers many possible combinations of the parameter values rather than an exhaustive search of extreme values [22]. However, ‘a large amount of computations is required to get a good solution in the presence of large parameters’ uncertainty’ [23].

The interval method is convenient to use in situations where underlying distributions for parameters are unknown, but the ranges are known or can otherwise be estimated. Ferson and Ginzburg [24] suggested that there is no need to assume ‘particular shapes for input distributions in probabilistic risk assessments’ and that it is ‘possible to make the needed calculations using inputs specified only as bounds on probability distributions’.

As mentioned by Huber [25], the MC method does not outweigh the potential for making incorrect decisions based on ‘forcing’ probability distributions when knowledge of those distributions does not exist. The interval approach is convenient when decision makers are interested, for example, in worst-case results only. MC approaches can better address descriptive sample statistics (e.g. mean, variance, and higher-order moments), while the interval approach obtains the strict bounds on outputs, thereby enabling calculation of the worst-case results.

Rocco [26] presented a preliminary idea to cope with the assessment of uncertainty propagation in Markov models. TR uncertainties were modelled as intervals and the approach was based on an algorithm whose operations were performed using basic IA concepts.

Ferson and Tucker [27] described an approach called ‘probability bounds analysis’, where the uncertainty about a probability distribution is modelled ‘by the set of cumulative distribution functions lying entirely within a pair of bounding distribution functions called a “probability box” or a “p-box”’. Then a p-box could be considered as ‘a hybrid of an interval and a probability distribution’ [28].

Basically there are two differences between IA and a p-box. The first is related to the type of uncertainty to be modelled. As suggested by Enszer et al. [28]: ‘If there are only upper and lower bounds on the uncertainties but no known probability distribution, then this can be represented by an interval. If there is some knowledge of the probability distribution, but it is uncertain, then this can be represented by a probability box (p-box).’ A uniform distribution could be used when only the lower and upper bounds are known. In this case, the bounds from a p-box and an interval will be the same.

The second difference is related to computational efforts. The p-box approach is based on p-box arithmetic, a set of convolution operations implemented through a discretization algorithm. The precision of such convolutions depends on the discretization step [28]. On the other hand, IA is based on a set of operations that do not require any discretization.

In this paper, TR uncertainties are modelled as intervals. A set of ad hoc procedures together with IA operations are proposed in order to define an enhanced approach that is able to produce better steady state probability bounds. To the present author’s best knowledge, comparisons of several classical and IA-based techniques for uncertainty propagation analysis in Markov models have not been presented elsewhere.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 defines the Markov model to be considered. Section 3 reviews some concepts of IA techniques while section 4 provides results of experimentation. Section 5 presents conclusions and future work.
The assumptions used in this work are as follows:

list-item.p: The system is in a steady state.
The time between two successive failures and the service time each follow an exponential distribution, and so the failure rate and the repair rate are constant; the process is stationary.
The number of states in the Markov models is finite.
The Markov chain is aperiodic and irreducible.

sec.title: 2 Markov Models
sec.p: A finite state continuous-time Markov chain Z = {z(t), t≥ 0}, with state space E = {1, 2, …, n} is used to model the transition of a system through different states that represent different operational components. For each i, j∈E, let λij be the TR from state i to state j. Let Q be the n × n TR matrix and Pi(t) be the probability that the system is in state i at time t. The Pi(t) values are obtained by solving the matrix differential equation
Let π = (π1, π2, …, πn)T be the steady state vector of Z. π can be found by solving the LS
The set of linear equations (1) is usually solved by classical decomposition methods (e.g. the lower diagonal upper decomposition technique) or by the Gauss–Seidel iterative method [5].
Since the numerical values of π depend on the values of the elements of Q, it is clear that their variations, which are due to uncertainties, will affect the value of probability πi.
Figure 1 shows the state space diagram for two identical repairable components [1].

caption.p: State space diagram for two identical repairable components

sec.p: The TR matrix is
From equations (1) and (2) the steady state probabilities πi can be obtained by solving the LS

If the λ and/or µ values are uncertain, with the bounds (λmin, λmax) and (µmin, µmax) respectively, their effects on the steady state probabilities could be studied by repeated solutions of equation (3). In this example, 22 LSs must be solved.

Theoretically the Q matrix is defined by n2 – n TRs, and so the number of uncertain factors is high, even for moderate values of n. This value assumes that there are TRs between all the states. In general, the number of different TRs is smaller because of some modelling assumptions, such as the existence of equal components or no-common cause transitions. For example, in the model in Fig. 1, there are only two different TRs, even if the three-state model could have six possible TRs. In this paper the number of different TRs is defined as k.

As previously mentioned, the set of linear equations (1) could be solved by classical numerical methods. However, in this paper the state reduction (SR) approach, proposed by Kumar and Billinton [29] is used. Their approach consists of an iterative procedure that reduces a state in each iteration ‘until the Markov system reduces to a 2-state model’. The procedure takes into account such reductions by modifying the TRs between states and state probabilities. The algorithm does not use any subtraction. As mentioned by Kumar and Billinton, the algorithm was developed to minimize the rounding and cancellation errors (e.g. during subtraction operations).
The SR algorithm is based on four steps:

list-item.p: calculation of the TRs of new Markov processes;
obtaining πi (i = 2, …, n) in terms of π1;

sec.title: 3 Interval Arithmetic
sec.p: IA originates from the recognition that frequently there is uncertainty associated with the parameters used in a computation. This form of mathematics ‘uses interval numbers’, which are actually an ordered pair of real numbers representing the lower and upper bounds of the parameter range [30]. For example, if it is known that the failure rate λ is between 36 h−1 and 44 h−1, the corresponding interval number would be written as follows: λ = [36, 44] h−1.
IA is built upon a basic set of axioms. Given two interval numbers X = [a, b] and Y = [c, d] with a≤b and c≤d, then the natural operations are defined as [30]

Only some of the algebraic laws valid for real numbers remain valid for intervals. It is easy to show that interval addition and multiplication are associative as well as commutative. However, the distributive law does not always hold for IA [31]. As an example, if X = [0, 1], then X*(1 – 1) = [0, 1]*(1 – 1) = 0, while X–X = [0, 1] – [0, 1] = [–1, 1].

An important property, referred to as subdistributivity, holds. It is given mathematically by the set inclusion relationship X(Y + Z) ⊆XY + XZ. The failure of the distributive law often causes overestimation; the interval width of the resulting operation is greater than the exact interval width. In the previous example the width of [0, 1](1 – 1) is zero while [0, 1] – [0, 1] = [–1, 1] has a width of 2.

In general, when a given variable appears more than once in an interval computation, it is treated as a different variable in each occurrence. Thus X – X is the same as X – Y with Y equal to but independent of X and causes the widening of the computed interval. This effect is called the ‘dependency problem’ [31]. However, there are expressions where dependence does not lead to overestimation, such as X + X [32].

One useful tactic to avoid dependence is to rewrite a given expression so that variables appear no more than once. For example, consider a two-state component with failure rate λ and repair rate μ. The steady state availability is given as [1]
If the failure rate and the repair rate are represented as the intervals λ = [1, 2] h−1 and μ = [3, 6] h−1, then
with an interval width of 1.5 – 0.375 = 1.125.
However, equation (4) could be written as
Now μ appears once and the exact range of variation for availability is evaluated as
with an interval width of 0.86 – 0.60 = 0.26.

Comparing the two results, it is clear that the interval width of the last interval is less than the interval width obtained using equation (4). This example shows that the first expression produces an overestimation. However, note that [0.60, 0.86] ⊆ [0.375, 1.5].

This overestimation could pose a problem to a decision maker trying to assess the behaviour of a system. For example the results using equation (4) suggest that the uncertainty in the failure and repair rates produces a lower bound for the availability of 0.375, while the exact lower bound is 0.60. That means that the lower bound from equation (4) is 62.5 per cent lower.

An interval vector is a vector whose components are intervals. An interval matrix is a matrix whose elements are intervals. For example, the two-dimensional interval vector Z = [X, Y], is represented geometrically by a rectangle (box). If the TRs are considered as interval numbers, then equation (3) transforms into an interval LS of equations.
Let A be a real matrix with elements aij, and let AI be an interval matrix with elements Aij. It is said that ‘A is contained in AI(A⊆AI )’ if and only if aij⊆Aij.
Consider the real LS of equations
If AI is an interval matrix bounding A, and bI is an interval vector bounding b, then equation (5) could be replaced by

The interval solution to equation (6) will contain the solution to equation (5). However, the solution of interval linear equations is a very different proposition from the solution of ordinary linear equations. The solution set is not generally an interval vector. Figure 2 illustrates the solutions set for the system [31]

caption.p: The solution set for equation (7) (adapted from reference [31])

sec.p: The inner region is the exact solution set. As the solution set is generally so complicated in shape, it is usually impractical to try to use it. Instead, it is common practice to seek an interval vector X containing the solution set known as the hull of the solution set [31].

The hull of the solution set associated with equation (7) is the interval vector X = [[–120, 90], [–60, 240]]T. This means that x varies in [–120, 90] while y∈ [–60, 240]. Note that the hull contains, in addition to the entire solution set, many non-solutions.

Solving interval linear equations means obtaining the hull of the solution set. By analogy with the real cases, equation (6) could be solved by decomposition methods or by the Gauss–Seidel iterative method; every operation is performed by interval operations, using for example object-oriented techniques [33] or calling special interval routines [34].

However, ordinary forward and back substitutions result in considerable overestimation of the solution, owing to the dependency problem and failure of the distributive law. The best solution to the problem of excessive conservatism in linear equation solving is to use the Gauss–Seidel iterative method [31, 35]. In order to converge to a solution, this method requires that the matrix be an M matrix (interval version of a diagonal dominant system). M matrices are defined as follows: a matrix A is an M matrix if Aij≤ 0 for all i≤j and Au > 0 for some positive vector u∈I(Rn) [31, 35].

If the matrix is an M matrix, the hull of the solution set can be guaranteed by the Gauss–Seidel method. Unfortunately, the matrix associated with the LS (1) is not an M matrix. For matrices which are not M matrices, other general techniques may be used (e.g. preconditioning [35, 36]) but it is not possible to know, a priori, the effect of overestimation.

In this paper instead of solving the LS of equations (1), a modification of the SR algorithm [29] is proposed to obtain the hull of steady state probabilities. As previously mentioned, SR does not involve any subtraction, and so the algorithm could be used to reduce the ‘interval’ dependency problem.

The SR algorithm together with particular IA procedures to avoid the ‘dependency problem’ allow the implementation of the interval version of the state reduction (ISR) algorithm. The bounds for the steady state probabilities are obtained with only one run of the ISR algorithm.
In order to reduce the dependency problem, some expressions in the original algorithm were rewritten so that variables appear no more than once.
For example, step (d) of the algorithm (see section 2) is rewritten as
Thus, πi appears no more than once.

sec.title: 4 Examples
sec.p: Several examples are presented in this section to compare three different approaches for determining the steady state probability bounds under TR uncertainties:

TR uncertainties are modelled as interval numbers; their bounds are defined from the base case values ± 10 per cent. For MC simulation it is assumed that the TRs are properly modelled as random variables with a uniform PDF. For each sample, the original SR is used to obtain the steady state probabilities. In all examples, 50 000 samples are evaluated.

sec.title: 4.1 Example 1: a series compensated power transmission line
sec.p: Rocco [26] analysed a four-state Markov model, representing a series compensated 400 kV transmission line. The model shown in Fig. 3 is used as part of a least-cost evaluation of a transmission planning study for the interconnection between two regional power systems. The base case values for the TRs of transmission equipment are shown in Table 1. The effects of ±10 per cent variations in the TRs are evaluated.

caption.p: State diagram for a series compensated line
Basic data for example 1

sec.p: Exact bounds for the steady state probabilities were obtained by solving the 24 = 16 LSs associated with Fig. 3, taking into account all the combinations of λL, λC, μL, and μC bounds. As shown in Table 2, the steady state probabilities calculated by the ISR algorithm (only one run is required) and MC simulation are very close to those obtained by solving 16 LSs. Note that the bounds from an LS or MC simulation are included in the ISR solutions. Figures 4 and 5 show the bounds derived by the different approaches.

caption.p: Bounds on the steady state probabilities for example 1
Bounds on the steady state probabilities obtained by different approaches for example 1
Bounds on the steady state probabilities obtained by different approaches for example 1: details for states 2 to 4

sec.title: 4.2 Example 2: power system with four units
sec.p: The system has been analysed in reference [14]. It consists of two generators C1 and C2 and two transformer units C3 and C4. Table 3 shows the 15 states defined for this system where O means an operating state, S denotes a standby state, and F corresponds to a failed state.

caption.p: System states for example 2

sec.p: The base-case TRs for the components are defined in Table 4: λI is the failure rate, λis is the failure rate in a shared resource or load, and I is the repair rate. In total there are 11 different TRs, and so 211 = 2048 LSs are solved. Table 5 shows the steady state probability bounds for the system.

caption.p: TR data for example 2
Bounds on the steady state probabilities for example 2

sec.p: As in the previous examples, the steady state probabilities calculated by the ISR algorithm and MC simulation are very close to those obtained by solving 2048 LSs. Note that the bounds from an LS or MC simulation are included in the ISR solutions, and the bounds from MC simulation are included in the LS bounds. Figures 6 and 7 show the bounds obtained by the different approaches.

caption.p: Bounds on the steady state probabilities obtained by different approaches for example 2
Bounds on the steady state probabilities obtained by different approaches for example 2: details for states 2 to 15

sec.title: 4.3 Example 3: Caracas Metro System
sec.p: This example is related to the design of Línea 2 of the Caracas Metro System in Venezuela [37]. Figure 8 shows the simplified state system of one train. It consists of the following five states: O, normal operating; D, total failure (distress) (the train is immobilized on the track and cannot move on its own); H, partial failure (light running) (the train is not immobilized and can clear the track on its own without passengers); S, stabling (the train’s attendant is able to repair the train and to restart it); P, provisional (the train is being repaired off the track).

caption.p: Simplified state space for each train

sec.p: Figure 9 shows the 26-state diagram of the ‘train system’ which includes 20 operating trains and one standby train. Table 6 shows the details for each state.

caption.p: State space for example 3
Details of each state for example 3

sec.p: The model considers only the states including more than 15 operating trains. States with 15 operating trains or less are considered as system failure states.
The following TRs are considered:
λD = failure rate for the distress failure mode
λH = failure rate for the light running failure mode
λR = failure rate for the interchange failure mode
λS = failure rate for the stabling failure mode
μH = repair rate corresponding to the clearing of the track after the train, leading to a light running failure distress failure mode
μD = repair rate corresponding to the clearing of the track after the train, leading to a distress failure mode
μS = repair rate corresponding to the clearing of the track after the train, leading to a stabling failure mode
μP = repair rate of a train in the workshop

Table 7 lists the description of the TRs between states. The base-case TRs for the components are defined in Table 8. In total there are eight different TRs. This means that 28 = 256 LSs must be solved under the LS approach.

caption.p: Equivalence between TRs in Fig. 5
TR data for example 3

sec.p: Table 9 shows the bounds associated with each steady state probability, owing to uncertainty propagation effects. Again, the steady state probabilities calculated by the three different approaches are very close. Figures 10 and 11 show the bounds obtained by the LS approach, MC simulation, and the ISR algorithm.

caption.p: Bounds on the steady state probabilities for example 3
Bounds on the steady state probabilities obtained by different approaches for example 3
Bounds on the steady state probabilities obtained by different approaches for example 3: details for states 4 to 26

sec.title: 4.4 Example 4: 20-state model
sec.p: This example is used to assess the behaviour of the ISR algorithm with many TRs. Figure 12 shows a 20-state model with 62 independent TRs. All 62 TRs are assumed to be uncertain with the base values defined as λij = 0.000 45t−1 if i > j, and λij = 0.0040 t−1 in other cases. (These TRs correspond to the failure rate and the repair rate for generator C1 in example 2.)

caption.p: 20-state model for example 4

sec.p: The exact bounds of the steady state probabilities require 262 = 4.6 × 1018 LSs to be solved. In this case, only the bounds obtained by the ISR algorithm and MC simulation are presented (Fig. 13).

caption.p: Bounds on the steady state probabilities obtained by different approaches for example 4

sec.title: 5 Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, the uncertainty propagation for the Markov steady state probabilities is assessed using an IA-based approach: first, uncertainties in the TRs between states are modelled, under the ‘unknown but bounded’ approach, by interval numbers; second, owing to dependency problems, techniques to solve interval LSs are not recommended. Therefore the ISR algorithm is proposed as an alternative method to evaluate uncertainty propagation.

IA takes into consideration the uncertainty of all the parameters and is able to provide strict bounds with only one evaluation. It is also possible to perform a sensitivity and uncertainty analysis by using IA, assigning bounds to some or all input parameters, and observing the effect on the final interval outcome.

The examples presented show that the bounds from the ISR algorithm are very similar to those obtained by solving 2k LSs or by MC simulation. The first approach is useful if the number of uncertain TRs is small (say, less than 16). MC simulation is able to model uncertainties which are represented as a PDF; a large amount of samples are required to obtain almost exact bounds, but MC simulation does not guarantee that the exact solution is contained in its bounds [27, 28].

However, even if appropriate tactics were used to reduce the IA dependency problem, the width of the interval probabilities from the ISR algorithm are always greater than the width from the LS approach. The next step in the investigation is the use of alternative methods, such as affine arithmetic (AA) [38] to reduce these widths. AA is an extension of IA which is able to track ‘the dependency between variables throughout calculations’ [39].

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: IA interval arithmetic
ISR interval version of state reduction
k number of different transition rates
LS linear system
MC Monte Carlo
n number of states
PDF probability density function
Q transition rate matrix
SR state reduction
TR transition rate
λij transition rate from state i to state j
π steady state probability vector = (π1, π2, …, πn)T
πi steady state probability of state i
